title: Disputing Eviction with Procedural Defects
summary: Used by tenants to challenge an eviction when the landlord failed to serve proper notice or followed incorrect legal procedures. Suitable for secure tenancy cases involving notice or claim form issues.

title: Tenant’s Defence and Disrepair Counterclaim
summary: For tenants facing eviction who also want to raise property disrepair issues (e.g. mould, leaks). Allows tenants to claim compensation and offset rent arrears under the Landlord and Tenant Act 1985.

title: Defence Involving Disability Discrimination and Procedure Errors
summary: Used when a tenant with a disability is facing eviction and wants to argue discrimination under the Equality Act 2010, alongside problems in the landlord’s legal process.

title: Defence Based on Human Rights and Procedural Issues
summary: Used to defend against eviction by arguing the landlord's actions violate the tenant’s right to a home (Article 8 of the Human Rights Act) and that legal procedures were not followed properly.

title: Challenging Eviction for Multiple Legal Errors
summary: Used by tenants to defend against eviction when several issues exist with the landlord’s notice or claim form. Focuses on legal flaws in the possession process.

title: Defence Involving Public Authority and Legal Process
summary: For tenants being evicted by a council or housing association. Challenges the fairness and legality of the decision-making process, especially if key facts were ignored.

title: Defending Against Possession Claim for Being Unreasonable
summary: Used to argue that the eviction is unfair or disproportionate given the tenant’s personal circumstances, such as health issues or efforts to resolve problems.

title: Claim Form Errors in Eviction Proceedings
summary: Used to challenge an eviction based on mistakes in the claim form or missing legal details. Helps tenants argue that the landlord’s claim is invalid or incomplete.

title: Defence Against Property Damage Accusation
summary: For tenants wrongly accused of damaging the property. Disputes the landlord’s right to evict based on false or unfair claims of damage or neglect.

title: Defence with Disrepair and Rent Offset
summary: Used to argue that poor property conditions justify a rent reduction and prevent eviction. Focuses on the landlord’s failure to maintain the property.

title: Defence for Disability Discrimination
summary: Helps tenants facing eviction due to disability-related issues. Argues that the eviction is discriminatory or that the landlord failed to make reasonable adjustments.

title: Defending with Human Rights Arguments
summary: Used to argue that eviction would breach the tenant’s human rights, such as disrupting family life or causing serious harm. Based on Article 8 of the Human Rights Act.

title: Notice Not Served Before Eviction Attempt
summary: Used when the landlord failed to serve a valid notice before starting eviction proceedings. Focuses on missing or defective legal notices.

title: Claim Errors in Eviction Documents
summary: For tenants disputing possession due to errors in the Particulars of Claim. Helps challenge the eviction based on incomplete or incorrect legal forms.

title: Defending Against Protocol Breaches
summary: Used to argue that the landlord (especially a housing association) failed to follow the required Pre-Action Protocol steps before starting eviction. Covers lack of warnings, support, or mediation.

title: Public Law Defence in Council Eviction Cases
summary: Used when a tenant believes the council failed to consider their circumstances, support needs, or acted unfairly. Challenges the legality of the eviction decision.

title: Unreasonable Possession Claim Defence
summary: Used by tenants in rent arrears who believe eviction would be unfair, such as delays in housing benefits or temporary income loss. Highlights steps taken to fix the situation.
